references: IUCN. 2014. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1. http://www.iucnredlist.org. Downloaded March 2016.
Lohoefener, R. and R.L. Jones. 1991. Status survey of Plethodon fourchensis and P. caddoensis. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Endangered Species Office, Status Survey Report, Jackson, Mississippi.

Anthony, C.D. 2005. Plethodon fourchensis (Highton 1979), Fourche Mountain Salamander. In Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA. p. 808.

Plummer, M.V. 1982. The status of the Caddo Mountain and Fourche Mountain salamanders (Plethodon caddoensis, P. fourchensis) in Arkansas. Report to the Arkansas Natural Heritage Commission, Little Rock, Arkansas.
Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.
Duncan, R., and R. Highton. 1979. Genetic relationships of the eastern large PLETHODON of the Ouachita Mountains. Copeia 1979:95-110.
habitat_description: Plethodon fourchensis was previously considered a variant of P. ouachitae (Rich Mountain salamanader) and orginally described by Duncan and Highton (1979) (Anthony 2005). Wilson (1995) describes habitat: "This salamander inhabits forested ridges and slopes, seeking shelter under rotting logs, rocks, and leaf litter. It often lives in rock crevices or fissures." This species is commonly foundat higher elevations of mixed deciduous, north-facing wooded slopes and deep ravines (Plummer 1982, Anthony 2005). Abundance appears related to site wetness, canopy cover, and plant diversity (Lohoefener and Jones 1991).
